keywhiz.auth

Class Subtles

  • java.lang.Object
    • keywhiz.auth.Subtles

  • public final class Subtles
extends Object
    Cryptographic utility methods that are somewhat subtle. Named in honor of Go's 'subtle' package.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static boolean secureCompare(byte[] a, byte[] b)
      Compare two byte arrays in constant time, so as to protect against timing attacks.
      static boolean secureCompare(char[] a, char[] b)
      Compare two char arrays in constant time, so as to protect against timing attacks.
      static boolean secureCompare(String a, String b)
      Compare two Strings in constant time, so as to protect against timing attacks.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • secureCompare

        public static boolean secureCompare(byte[] a,
                                    byte[] b)
        Compare two byte arrays in constant time, so as to protect against timing attacks. (NB: "Constant time" means that the method execution time does not depend on the contents of the buffer — it's not a comment about the time complexity. (The method is obviously O(n).) This is interesting because normal comparisons (Arrays.equals(), eg) short-circuit as soon as a difference is found. This leaks information about the underlying data, and so is inappropriate for comparing secrets. For more information, see:
        • this Square Security Awareness note
        • a discussion of Java 6's MessageDigest.isEqual()
        • a paper on the practical exploitability of network-based timing attacks
        Parameters:
        a - first value
        b - second value
        Returns:
        true iff a == b

      • secureCompare

        public static boolean secureCompare(char[] a,
                                    char[] b)
        Compare two char arrays in constant time, so as to protect against timing attacks. (NB: "Constant time" means that the method execution time does not depend on the contents of the buffer — it's not a comment about the time complexity. (The method is obviously O(n).) This is interesting because normal comparisons (Arrays.equals(), eg) short-circuit as soon as a difference is found. This leaks information about the underlying data, and so is inappropriate for comparing secrets. For more information, see:
